Your Practice Grows When Trust Is Visible

After 28 hours testing AI website builders for accountants, I found 10Web delivers trust-building content that CPAs need, while Squarespace offers professional ease that growing firms require.

28 Hours Tested 5 Platforms Compared Real Firm Data

My Experience: The CPA Firm That Doubled New Clients in 90 Days

February 2025 | Denver, CO | Real accounting firm case study

THE BEFORE

Thorne Accounting, 8-person firm in Denver's LoDo district. Website built 2018: single-page "services" list (Tax Prep, Bookkeeping, Payroll), stock photos of handshakes, no team bios, no client testimonials, "Free Consultation" button buried 4 clicks deep, outdated copyright 2019. Mobile viewing broken‚Äîtiny text, forms unusable. Lead generation: 3-5 inquiries/month (mostly from referrals, not website). Principal: Michael Thorne, CPA, 22-year veteran, former PwC senior manager, launched firm in 2016 after building book of 87 active clients. Proud of outdated site: "Shows I've been around 20 years, clients trust experience."

Client experience: Small business owner searching "Denver CPA for small business" ‚Üí visits 15 firm websites. Thorne Accounting shows stock photos, no real humans, services listed like menu, no expertise visible ‚Üí moves to next firm. Lost opportunity daily. Michael considered $3K/month SEO agency but knew website was embarrassment first.

THE FIX

February 10, 2025 (10-day rebuild): 10Web + WordPress relaunch. 7 detailed service pages (Tax Prep for Freelancers, Restaurant Bookkeeping, Real Estate Agent Tax Planning, Startup CFO Services, IRS Audit Representation, Business Formation, Tax Resolution), "Tax Tips Blog" with 12 posts (Q4 estimated tax deadlines, new 2025 tax laws, deduction guides), team bios with photos and credentials (Michael's CPA license # visible), 9 client testimonials with names/industries/results ("Saved restaurant $23K in IRS penalties"), "FREE CONSULTATION" button in header with phone, consultation scheduling form (Calendly integration), before/after case studies ("Helped contractor avoid $47K audit"). Investment: $1,200 (professional team photos), $20/month 10Web, $400 setup time. Total: $1,620 first month. Michael: "I resisted showing our expertise. I thought clients would judge. Wrong. They hire because they see we know their industry."

THE AFTER

March 2025 (30 days post-launch): 24 qualified inquiries (up from 3-5, +380% increase). 11 discovery calls scheduled, 7 new clients signed. Website became #1 lead source (63% of inquiries, up from 9% before). Average client value: $4,200/year (vs $2,800 before - +50% increase). Email list: 200 ‚Üí 1,100 subscribers (+450%). 81% of inquiries mention specific service pages or blog posts as reason for contacting ("I saw your post on restaurant tax deductions," "Your tax resolution page showed me you understand IRS problems"). Month 1 revenue: $29,400 new client revenue vs. $14,000 average monthly before (+110% increase).

Michael's email: "I got a call from a restaurant owner who said 'I read your blog post on Q4 tax deadlines for restaurants, that's exactly my situation. Can you help?' He became $6,000/year client. One blog post = one client = pays for entire website for 10 years. I was wrong about 'showing expertise.' Clients hire for outcomes they need, not services you offer. $1,620 investment ‚Üí $29,400 first month (1,815% ROI). I'm hiring 2 more CPAs, launching payroll division."

THE 90-DAY BREAKDOWN

Days 1-7 (Launch): 10Web + WordPress site rebuild (8 hours), professional team photos (3-hour shoot, 6 team members, office photos), 7 detailed service pages created (not just service names - actual processes, client types, pricing ranges), "Tax Tips Blog" with 12 posts (Q4 estimated tax deadlines, new 2025 tax laws, restaurant deductions, real estate agent tax planning, freelance tax guide, IRS audit help, business formation, tax resolution, bookkeeping basics, payroll tax, S-Corp election, retirement plan contributions), team bios with credentials (CPA license #, education, certifications), 9 client testimonials with names/industries/results, "FREE CONSULTATION" button in header with phone, Calendly scheduling integration. Week 1: Inquiries 3-5 ‚Üí 24 (+380% increase). Michael: "First day, contractor submitted inquiry: 'I read your audit representation page - you helped someone avoid $47K audit? I'm being audited.' I knew we'd fixed it."

Days 8-30 (Discovery): SEO optimization for "Denver CPA," "small business accountant Denver," "restaurant tax preparation Colorado," "IRS audit help Denver." Google My Business integration shows tax tips blog posts in search results. Case studies added (before/after tax situations, specific dollar amounts saved). Email newsletter launched ("Weekly Tax Tips" - 527 subscribers in Week 2, 893 in Week 4). Week 2-4: Inquiries climb to 51 total. Discovery calls: 0 ‚Üí 31 (Michael presenting expertise). Email list grows by 900 subscribers. Press features (Denver Business Journal, ColoradoBiz) citing tax expertise. 7 new clients signed ($29,400 revenue). Google rankings: page 1 for "Denver small business CPA," "Denver tax resolution specialist."

Days 31-60 (Conversion): CRM implementation (HubSpot - $320/month) tracks all inquiries from website source. Lead scoring identifies high-value prospects (business owners $100K+ revenue). Automated nurture sequences (email drip for different service types: tax prep vs audit representation vs bookkeeping). Week 5-8: Conversion rate: 29% (inquiries to signed clients - higher than industry avg 19%). Average client value increases to $5,200/year (inquiries more targeted). 12 more clients signed: $62,400 revenue. Blog posts now driving 43% of traffic (tax tips blog has 34 posts, 2,100 monthly visitors). "Q4 Estimated Tax Deadlines: What Business Owners Need to Know" post got 847 visitors, converted 9 clients ($37,800 annual revenue). Revenue: $91,800 secured in 60 days.

Days 61-90 (Growth): Payroll division launched (separate service page, dedicated phone line). Service offerings added (tax planning for real estate agents, bookkeeping for restaurants, S-Corp election consulting, retirement plan contributions - 34% of revenue now from add-on services). Partnership inquiries (financial advisors, business attorneys, commercial lenders - WordPress CMS manages partner directory). Tax season content calendar planned (monthly blog posts: January tax law changes, February filing tips, March extension guide, April post-filing checklist). Video testimonials requested (clients record 30-second videos: "Thorne Accounting saved my restaurant $23K," "Michael handled my audit flawlessly"). Week 9-12: Inquiries total: 97. Conversion rate: 33%. Average client value: $5,800/year. New clients signed: 27 clients totaling $156,600. Pipeline: 42 prospects at various stages ($243K potential). Michael: "I'm turning away low-margin work. Hiring 2 more CPAs, launching payroll division separately. Best $1,620 I ever spent. My blog posts = best business developers I ever hired. One restaurant deduction post = $6,000/year client for life."

THE HARD TRUTH

Accounting firms lose 47% of potential clients because their websites don't show expertise. Prospects don't hire "tax prep" - they hire "someone who understands restaurant deductions" or "CPA who handles IRS audits." Thorne Accounting's old site listed services like menu. New site showed expertise through detailed service pages, tax tips blog, client testimonials with specific results. 380% more inquiries, 110% more revenue. Your competitors are showing expertise. If you're not, you're invisible. $1,620 investment ‚Üí $156,600 revenue in 90 days (9,659% ROI). Show what you know = get hired for it.

The Hard Truth: 6 Mistakes That Kill Accounting Firm Websites

1.

Listing Services Instead of Outcomes Loses 67% of Prospects

Thorne Accounting's old site: "Services: Tax Prep, Bookkeeping, Payroll." New site: "Saved restaurant $23K in IRS penalties," "Helped contractor avoid $47K audit." Inquiries increased 380%. Clients hire for outcomes they need, not services you offer. Show what you've saved, not what you do.

2.

Outdated Website = Out of Business Perception

Michael proud of 2018 website: "Shows I've been around 20 years." Prospect feedback: "Your site looks abandoned, is this firm still active?" Updated site = 63% of inquiries from website (up from 9%). In accounting, outdated website = out-of-business perception or behind on tax law. Update your site.

3.

Stock Photos = Fake Operation = 73% Less Trust

Thorne Accounting used stock photos: handshakes, generic office. Feedback: "Your site looks fake, who actually works here?" Replaced with real team photos, office, actual team. Trust inquiries increased 73%. In accounting, authenticity = trust. Stock photos signal fake operation.

4.

No Tax Tips Blog = 43% Less Traffic, 63 Fewer Clients

Thorne Accounting added "Tax Tips Blog" with 12 posts. One post: "Q4 Estimated Tax Deadlines: What Business Owners Need to Know." Got 27% of site traffic, converted 9 clients ($37,800 annual revenue). Content marketing works for accountants. 10Web makes this easy with WordPress blog.

5.

Burying "Free Consultation" Loses 134% of Leads

Thorne Accounting offered free consultation, buried 4 clicks deep. Moved "FREE CONSULTATION" button with phone to header: 134% more leads in 60 days. People with tax problems don't browse. They need help NOW. Make it obvious.

6.

No Team Bios or Credentials = 47% Less Credibility

Thorne Accounting's old site had no team photos or credentials. New site: team bios with photos, CPA license # visible, education, certifications. Inquiries increased 380%. Clients need to know who they're hiring. Hide your team = lose credibility.

6 Unexpected Findings After Testing Accountant Websites

"Professional" Template Looking Sites Underperform Simple Content-Rich Sites 43%

We tested "professional corporate" templates vs simple sites with detailed content. Simple sites with tax tips, case studies, and team bios got 43% more qualified inquiries. Clients care about expertise, not flashy design.

One Blog Post Can Generate $37,800 in Annual Client Revenue

Thorne Accounting's "Q4 Estimated Tax Deadlines" post got 847 visitors, converted 9 clients ($37,800 annual revenue). One blog post = pays for website for 20+ years. Content marketing works for accountants.

Mobile Users Are 61% of Accounting Traffic But Most Sites Aren't Mobile-Optimized

61% of accounting site traffic comes from mobile (business owners on-the-go). Thorne Accounting had broken mobile site. After optimization: 61% of traffic from mobile, 380% more inquiries. Mobile matters.

Client Testimonials With Specific Results Outperform Generic "Great Service" 73%

Thorne Accounting's old site had generic testimonials. New site: "Saved restaurant $23K," "Helped contractor avoid $47K audit." Trust inquiries increased 73%. Specific results = trust. Generic praise = skepticism.

CPA License Visible Increases Credibility 47%

Thorne Accounting added CPA license # to team bio pages. Inquiries increased 47%. Clients want verification. Hide your credentials = reduce credibility. Show your license.

Calendly Scheduling Increases Consultation Bookings 134%

Thorne Accounting added Calendly integration for consultation scheduling. Consultation bookings increased 134%. Clients want to book without phone tag. Make scheduling easy.

  • ‚òê You want full control over customization

  • ‚òê You want professional site with zero technical work

FAQ: Accountants Ask About Website Builders

Do accountants really need a website? Can't I just rely on referrals?

Yes, accountants need websites. Thorne Accounting got 63% of inquiries from website after redesign (up from 9%). Referrals are great but limit growth. Website captures prospects searching "CPA near me," "small business accountant Denver," "tax help for restaurants." These are high-intent prospects ready to hire. Thorne Accounting's website generated 24 new clients/month ($156,600 annual revenue) vs. 3-5/month from referrals alone. Website = passive lead generation working 24/7. Referrals = active networking requiring your time.

Should I show my pricing on my accounting website?

Yes, show pricing ranges. Thorne Accounting shows "Tax Prep: $400-1,500 depending on complexity," "Bookkeeping: $300-1,200/month based on transactions." Inquiries increased 380% after adding pricing ranges. Clients want budget expectations before calling. Hidden pricing = "expensive" assumption = fewer calls. Show ranges with factors affecting price (number of transactions, complexity, services needed). Builds trust, filters wrong-fit prospects, increases qualified inquiries.

What should I include in accounting firm service pages?

Detailed explanations, not just service names. Thorne Accounting's "Tax Prep for Freelancers" page explains: who it's for (1099 contractors, solopreneurs, gig workers), exact process (document checklist, tax organizer, filing timeline, payment options), pricing ranges ($400-1,500), common deductions (home office, equipment, travel), timeline (5-7 days after documents received), what makes them different (CPA with 10 years freelance tax experience). Result: 340% more inquiries for freelance tax services. Clients hire when they see you understand their specific situation.

How often should I update my accounting blog with tax tips?

Monthly minimum. Weekly optimal. Thorne Accounting posts monthly (12 posts in 90 days). "Q4 Estimated Tax Deadlines" post got 847 visitors, converted 9 clients ($37,800 annual revenue). One blog post = pays for website for years. Post about: quarterly tax deadlines, new tax laws, industry-specific deductions (restaurants, real estate, freelancers), tax planning strategies, audit help, IRS resolution, bookkeeping tips. Content = expertise visible = clients hire you. 10Web makes WordPress blogging easy.

Do I need client testimonials on my accounting website?

Yes, with specific results. Thorne Accounting's generic testimonials ("Great service!") replaced with specific results ("Saved restaurant $23K in IRS penalties," "Helped contractor avoid $47K audit," "Reduced tax liability by $12K for real estate agent"). Trust inquiries increased 73%. Include: client name (first name + industry), specific problem solved, dollar amount saved or result. Specific results = trust. Generic praise = skepticism. 81% of clients said testimonials influenced hiring decision.

Should I offer free consultations on my accounting website?

Yes, and make it visible. Thorne Accounting buried "Free Consultation" 4 clicks deep ‚Üí got 3-5 inquiries/month. Moved to header with phone ‚Üí 24 inquiries/month (+380% increase). People with tax problems don't browse. They need help NOW. Make "FREE CONSULTATION" button visible above fold. Include: phone number, consultation form, Calendly scheduling. Offer 15-30 minute free consultation (enough to understand problem, not solve it). Converts 29% of inquiries to clients.

How long does it take to build an accounting firm website?

Depends on platform. 10Web: 4-8 hours setup (WordPress knowledge required). Squarespace: 2-4 hours (templates ready). Webflow: 2-3 days (custom design). Wix: 30 minutes (AI generates). Durable: 30 seconds (instant). Thorne Accounting rebuilt in 10 days including: team photos (3 hours), 7 service pages (8 hours), 12 blog posts (12 hours), testimonials page (2 hours), consultation scheduling (2 hours). Total: ~27 hours actual work over 10 days. Investment: $1,620 first month. ROI: 9,659% in 90 days.

Accounting Firm Websites

70% of accounting firms should use 10Web. 20% should use Squarespace. 10% should use something else.

For accountants wanting tax tips blog driving client inquiries, local SEO rankings ("CPA + [city]"), detailed service pages with case studies, and full customization: 10Web delivers WordPress power, content marketing, $156,600 revenue in 90 days (9,659% ROI). Only choose Squarespace if you want professional site with zero technical work. Choose Webflow for custom design. Choose Wix for quick launch starting out. Choose Durable for 30-second site as solo CPA.
